title-group.article-title: The relationship between displacement and clinical outcome after distal radius (Colles’) fracture

abstract.p: We reviewed 260 patients who had been treated non-operatively for a dorsally displaced distal radius fracture a mean 6.3 (range 2.5–12.7) years earlier, in an attempt to find the limits of displacement compatible with a good clinical outcome. We excluded patients with previous or later injuries to the same limb. Bivariate analysis revealed a highly statistically significant relationship between radiographic displacement at review and clinical outcome scores. Correlation coefficients varied between 0.14 and 0.30. However, multiple linear regression analysis using most factors commonly thought to be of importance in determining the clinical outcome as independent variables explained only 23% of the variability of the clinical outcome. Dorsal angulation, ulnar variance, and radial inclination together accounted for only 11% of the variability. We conclude that the final alignment of the distal radius as shown radiologically has only a minor influence on the clinical outcome of Colles’ type distal radius fractures.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Until fairly recently, most clinicians felt that Abraham Colles (1814) was correct when he stated that after dorsally displaced fractures of the distal radius the wrist would eventually regain very good or full function (Altissimi et al., 1986; Smail, 1965; Warwick et al., 1993). Historically, the large majority of these fractures were treated non-operatively, even when there was quite considerable remaining displacement of the distal radial fracture fragment. Recently, there has been greater emphasis on obtaining correct realignment of the skeleton in order to obtain a good clinical outcome. In spite of numerous studies, it is still unclear how much displacement may be acceptable.

When closed reduction fails to provide the desired realignment, operative options are available. Lately, open reduction and fixation with angular stable volar plates has become popular. In 2008, there were reported to be more than 30 different volar plating systems (Chen and Jupiter, 2007; Downing and Karantana, 2008). Their use varies from country to country and hospital to hospital. Some national societies have tried to formulate guidelines, but have only been able to put forward tentative recommendations (American Academy of Orthopedic Surgeons [AAOS], 2011; Hølmer et al., 2001). Nonetheless, the rate of volar plating of these fractures appears to be increasing. The practice in our department is probably fairly typical for Scandinavia: in 2009 and 2010 we treated 53% of patients with distal radius fractures over the age of 30 years by simply placing the wrist in a plaster of Paris (POP) cast; 22% with manipulation and plaster casting; and we performed open reduction and stabilization with volar plates in 19%. Similar patterns of treatment have also been reported from Oslo (Knut Melhuus, personal communication, 2007) and Sweden (Abramo et al., 2008).

Our hypothesis was that, although there is great heterogeneity in both patients and fractures of the distal radius, it would be possible to determine the limits to bony displacement that usually are compatible with a good clinical outcome by reviewing a sufficiently large number of patients treated non-operatively for a distal radius fracture.

sec.title: Methods
sec.p: We reviewed the case notes and radiographs of all patients treated non-operatively for dorsally displaced distal radial fractures at our hospital during 1997 and 1998, and between June 2003 and December 2006. Our inclusion criteria were fractures with initial displacement in a dorsal direction of at least 5° from the normal volar tilt of 10°. Our exclusion criteria were AO type B fractures (Muller et al., 1987); case-note or radiological evidence of previous or later injuries or conditions that might influence the long-term function of the injured or contralateral wrist; and patients who did not live in our city or three adjoining municipalities. We excluded patients under 30 years old at the time of fracture as many have high-energy comminuted fractures. We excluded patients over age 85 years, as they were unlikely to be available for review.

Patients who complied with our inclusion criteria were asked by letter to attend a review between June and September 2009. We assessed the history, looking at the mechanism and energy of injury, and other diseases or injuries that might influence function in the injured or contralateral wrist and hand at review. We measured the range of motion (ROM) of the forearm and wrist with a hand-held goniometer. We recorded the total wrist ROM, adding together the values for extension, flexion, ulnar deviation, and radial deviation. Values for supination and pronation were added together to give forearm motion. We measured grip strength in both hands using a Jamar dynamometer set at position two (A. Preston Corp., Clifton, New Jersey, USA). The median value of three attempts was recorded. For comparison, we increased the recorded value in the non-dominant hand by 10% (Bechtol, 1954; Földhazy et al., 2007; Kelly et al., 1997; MacDermid et al., 2002; Wilcke et al., 2007). Any losses of ROM or grip strength were calculated as a percentage of that of the uninjured wrist.

Pain during daily activities in the previous week before review was recorded on a visual analogue scale (VAS), where 0 denoted no pain and 100 worst imaginable pain. Patients completed the short version of the Disabilities of the Arm, Shoulder and Hand (Q-DASH) questionnaire (Finsen, 2008; Gummesson et al., 2006; Hudak et al., 1996) and the Patient Rated Wrist Evaluation (PRWE) (Changulani et al., 2008; MacDermid et al., 1998). The Q-DASH consists of 11 questions related to pain and function using both upper extremities, and the PRWE consists of 15 questions about pain and function only in the injured wrist. Both are scored from 0 (best) to 100 (worst).

Both wrists of each patient had posteroanterior and lateral radiographs. Fractures were classified according to the AO system (Muller et al., 1987). Dorsal angulation of the distal fragment and radial inclination were measured in relation to the long axis of the radius. Volar angles were given a negative value. Ulnar variance was measured as the axial difference between the articular surfaces of the ulna and radius at the distal radio-ulnar joint and given a positive value when the ulna was longer then the radius. Intra-articular fracture step-offs and fracture gaps were measured.

In addition to the PRWE and Q-DASH scores, we constructed a new composite score, the Global Wrist Outcome Score (GWOS), which combines subjective and objective outcomes. GWOS is scored between 0 (best) and 100 (worst). The PRWE contributes 50%; the VAS score for pain, 20%; loss of grip strength, 20%; and loss of wrist mobility, 10%. The score is arrived at by adding together the PRWE score divided by two, the VAS score for pain (on a scale of 0 to 100) divided by five, the percentage strength loss divided by five, and the percentage loss of wrist ROM divided by 10. Thus, pain contributes approximately 45% to the score; function, 25%; and objective findings (strength and mobility), 30%. Loss of supination and pronation were not included in the GWOS because they proved to be minimal. The GWOS correlated well with the PRWE (r = 0.907; p < 0.001) and Q-DASH (r = 0.764; p < 0.001). Data in the present paper were analyzed using all three scores, but the results are mainly presented for the GWOS.

We used scatter plots and Spearman’s correlation to find correlations between variables. Multiple linear regression analysis and ordinal regression analysis were used to evaluate to what extent the functional outcome at review could be explained by the data we had collected. We selected independent variables based on previous reports: radiographic measurements (dorsal angulation, radial inclination, ulnar variance, fracture classification, gap or step-off of intra-articular fractures, involvement of the distal radioulnar joint, and fracture of the ulnar styloid); complications; patients’ age; gender; and time between injury and review. Variables that did not significantly contribute in a multiple linear regression analysis were omitted in subsequent analyses.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: We invited 558 patients for review; 296 attended. Eight were excluded because of incomplete data or they did not fulfil the inclusion criteria. Four more were excluded because they had suffered high-energy trauma. Of the remainder, 24 patients had other injuries or conditions of the fractured extremity; thus, there remained 260 patients in whom outcome parameters based only on the injured limb could be calculated. Of these, 46 had injuries on the opposite limb making direct comparison invalid, leaving 214 patients for whom outcome parameters based on comparison between the two limbs could be calculated.

Of the 260 patients, there were 32 men and 228 women with a mean age at injury of 62 (range 30–84) years. The fractures were reduced with a haematoma block and application of a POP in 184 patients. The remaining 76 patients just had application of a POP. Mean time between injury and review was 6.3 (range 2.5–12.7) years.

Patients reported few verifiable complications. These included many problems that might have been unrelated to the fracture or were short term, but for completeness, we note them all: three clear cases of complex regional pain syndrome 1; six cases of carpal tunnel syndrome since the fracture; two cases of frozen shoulder; and one rupture of the extensor pollicis longus tendon. In addition, 16 patients had complained of a tight POP, 20 patients remembered pain for several months after the fracture, one reported some reduced sensibility in the hand at review, three reported occasional paraesthesia in the hand after the fracture, one had been treated for tenosynovitis of the wrist, and one developed Dupuytren’s disease, which he ascribed to the fracture. Student’s t-test revealed no significant difference in dorsal angulation or ulnar variance between patients with complications and those without. However, mean radial inclination was 17° among patients with complications and 20° among those without (p = 0.002).

Among the 214 patients with an uninjured contralateral extremity, there was a mean loss of grip strength of 12% (SD 18%), a loss of wrist mobility of 10% (SD 12%), and a loss of pronation and supination of 2% (SD 7%). For the full cohort of 260 patients, the mean score for pain was 6 (SD 15) on a scale of 0 to 100. Eighteen patients stated that they had had to change their work activities since the fracture.

Mean PRWE score was 11 (SD 16), mean Q-DASH score was 13 (SD 16) and mean GWOS score was 11 (SD 13). GWOS scores varied between 0 and 75; 77% had a score below 15, indicating that the scores were not normally distributed. This was also the case for Q-DASH and PRWE scores. Scatter plots of the chosen radiological parameters and GWOS (and also of PRWE and Q-DASH, data not shown) confirmed this and, furthermore, gave no indication of a significant association between clinical outcome scores and radiographic measurements (Figure 1).

sec.p: Subdivision of the outcome parameters gave the impression of poorer clinical outcome with increasing radiological displacement at review (Table 1). The standard errors of the means, however, indicate extensive overlap of the mean outcome scores at differing degrees of displacement.

sec.p: Spearman’s test showed a statistically significant correlation between each of the four radiographic measurements at review and PRWE, Q-DASH, and GWOS scores (Table 2). The correlation coefficients were between 0.14 and 0.30. In subsequent analyses ulnar variance, rather than radial length, was used to indicate radial shortening, as the latter depends on both radial shortening and decrease in radial inclination.

caption.p: Correlation (Spearman) of the recorded data with the Global Wrist Outcome Score (GWOS), Patient Rated Wrist Evaluation (PRWE), and Quick Disabilities of the Arm, Shoulder and Hand (Q-DASH) outcome scores

sec.p: Linear regression analysis (Table 3) showed that 23% of the variability (R2) of the GWOS was accounted for when one included the variables dorsal angulation at review, ulnar variance at review, radial inclination at review, time between fracture and review, age at injury, gender, treatment (reduced and casted or only casted), fracture type, fracture of the ulnar styloid, involvement of the distal radioulnar joint, step-off of the distal radial articular surface as seen on radiographs at review, and complications. The same analysis with PRWE as the dependent variable gave an R2 of 20%, and with the Q-DASH as the dependent variable, an R2 of 16%. Step-wise regression analysis revealed that only complications, ulnar variance, dorsal angulation, and time since fracture significantly contributed to GWOS and PRWE scores (R2 = 24% and 21%, respectively). Complications, radial inclination, time since fracture, and ulnar variance significantly contributed to the Q-DASH score (R2 = 16%). The significance of these factors was confirmed by ordinal regression.

Model 2: Predictors: dorsal angulation at review, ulnar variance at review, time between injury and review, and complications. Model 3: Predictors: radial inclination at review, dorsal angulation at review, ulnar variance at review

sec.p: Finally, a linear regression analysis was performed using only dorsal angulation at review, ulnar variance at review, and radial inclination at review as independent variables. These three variables together accounted for 11% of the variability of the GWOS, 7% of the variability of the DASH, and 6% of the variability of the PRWE.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: We only contacted patients living fairly close to our hospital in the hope that this would increase the likelihood that they would return for review. Even so, only just over half came for the review. A similarly low rate of follow-up is reported in previous studies (Abramo et al., 2008; Altissimi et al., 1986; Barton et al., 2007; Chung et al., 2007; Földhazy et al., 2007; Kopylov et al., 1993).

We selected 1997–98 initially because we wanted to include patients from a time when non-operative treatment was more common. We could not assess patients from before 1997 as their radiographs had been destroyed. In spite of treating approximately 500 distal radius fractures every year at our hospital, relatively few remained because of our exclusion criteria and because some radiographs had been lost. To increase the number of patients, we chose fractures sustained after June 2003 when our case-notes and radiographs were digitalized.

Ours is the only local hospital for our area. In spite of excluding the numerous patients where our case-notes indicated previous or later injuries that could influence function in either upper limb, a considerable number had to be excluded at review because they proved to have injuries that we had missed in our files or were unknown to us. Even though the prevalence of such confounding injuries is extremely high in the elderly population, it seems rarely to be taken into account in reviews of distal radius fracture (Abramo et al., 2008; Arora et al., 2009; Foreward et al., 2008; Solgaard, 1988).

We agree with other authors (Amadio et al., 1996; Changulani et al., 2008; Földazy et al., 2007; Foreward et al., 2008; MacDermid et al., 2002; Wilcke et al., 2007) that it seems reasonable to consider both objective and subjective data when evaluating the outcome after distal radius fractures. In order to reduce the risk of finding spurious significant correlations by having many outcome measures, we have amalgamated most of them into our GWOS. The weighting of the components of the score can be disputed. From clinical experience we feel that pain is the most serious problem after distal radius fracture, and we have allotted just under half the points to this, similar to the PRWE. We placed more weight on grip strength than on ROM, as it is our experience that even a fairly substantial loss of mobility has little impact on the daily activities of most patients (Jaremko et al., 2007; Nelson, 1997). It seemed reasonable to select the PRWE for our GWOS as it measures function only in the relevant wrist. Our score has not formally been validated, but shows a high degree of correlation not only with the PRWE, but also with Q-DASH. In the bivariate analyses of our data (Table 2), the GWOS was more closely associated with 18 of the 23 suggested predictors of outcome than was either the PRWE or Q-DASH.

There was a statistically significant correlation between radiological measurements at review and the functional result among our patients. However, this alone does not indicate the magnitude or importance of this association. Multiple regression analysis showed that its influence on the final clinical outcome was, in fact, quite small. Furthermore, we found that neither age, fracture type, fracture of the ulnar styloid, involvement of the DRUJ, or intra-articular step-off significantly influenced the final clinical outcome. Only a few of our patients had intra-articular displacement.

Unexpectedly, we found that time between injury and follow-up had a highly statistically significant influence on the clinical outcome, even though our shortest follow-up was 2.5 years. This might indicate that the final result after distal radius fracture has not been reached even 2.5 years after fracture. This has not been reported in other studies.

This is a retrospective study, which raises the question of whether our sample of patients is representative. The strengths of this study are that the patients we assessed had no previous disabilities of the upper extremities; that they were able to come to the review probably indicates they did not have a lower demand on their wrists than the average for their age; and many of the fractures healed with considerable displacement (Table 1). Thirty-six patients (14%) had a final dorsal angulation of > 20°, 38 (15%) an ulnar variance of > 5 mm, and 46 (18%) < 15° of radial inclination at review.

The decision to treat a distal radius fracture operatively is based primarily on radiographs during the first few days after injury, long before the clinical outcome is known. The patients who had surgery of their fracture therefore have no bearing on our findings. The main confounder is that some conservatively treated patients with painful wrists will have been treated with a corrective osteotomy or ulnar shortening. Between 2005 and 2009, we only performed corrective osteotomies for malunited distal radius fractures in eight patients from the municipalities chosen for this study. For geographical reasons, it is unlikely that they will have had the procedure performed at some other institution.

Although we felt that we had included most of the factors commonly assumed to be of importance in determining the outcome after distal radial fracture, most of the variation in the GWOS, PRWE, and Q-DASH scores could not be explained by our data. Factors such as physiotherapy (Kay et al., 2008) may be of importance for the final result. Grewal et al. (2007) found that injury compensation cases and length of education accounted for 16% of the variation in PRWE in 222 patients reviewed 1 year after fracture. Others have found injury compensation (MacDermid et al., 2002) and level of income (Chung et al., 2007) to be the strongest determinants of outcome.

Many experts feel that, as in most other fractures, re-establishing bony anatomy is important in order to obtain a good clinical outcome after a distal radius fracture. In 25 papers dealing with the association between radiological and clinical outcome after distal radius fracture, six found that none of the common radiological predictors was useful (Abramo et al., 2008; Chung et al., 2007; Kopylov et al., 1993; MacDermid et al., 2002; Smail, 1965; Stewart et al., 1985). Nine of the 25 studies found dorsal angulation to be of importance (Altissimi et al., 1986; Batra and Gupta, 2002; Brogren et al., 2011A; Dixon et al., 2005; Gliatis et al., 2000; Grewal and MacDermid, 2007; Pechlaner et al., 2007; Tsukazaki, 1993; Wilcke et al., 2007). Three concluded that the cut-off point was at 10° dorsal angulation (Brogren et al., 2011A; Gliatis et al., 2000; Grewal and MacDermid, 2007), and three at 15° (Altissimi et al., 1986; Dixon et al., 2005; Wilcke et al., 2007). Six of the 25 studies concluded that loss of radial inclination was important (Altissimi et al., 1986; Grewal and MacDermid, 2007; Jenkins and Mintowt-Czyz, 1988; Kumar et al., 2008; Pechlaner et al., 2007; Wilcke et al., 2007). Two found a cut-off point at 15° remaining radial inclination (Grewal and MacDermid, 2007; Kumar et al., 2008), one at 10° (Wilcke et al., 2007), and one at 5° (Altissimi et al., 1986).

Sixteen of the 25 studies found loss of radial length to be a predictor of clinical outcome (Altissimi et al., 1986; Batra and Gupta, 2002; Brogren et al., 2011A; Dixon et al., 2005; Földhazy et al., 2007; Foreward et al., 2008; Grewal and MacDermid, 2007; Karnezis et al., 2005; Kumar et al., 2008: Ng and McQueen, 2011; Pechlaner et al., 2007; Solgaard, 1988; Trumble et al., 1994; Villar et al., 1987; Warwick et al., 1993; Wilcke et al., 2007). Three papers reported this as radial height (Ng and McQueen, 2011; Solgaard, 1988; Villaret al., 1987) and one of them found a cut-off point at 2 mm (Ng and McQueen, 2011). The remainder reported radial shortening as ulnar variance. One paper found a cut-off point at 2 mm ulnar variance (Wilcke et al., 2007), two at 3 mm (Dixon et al., 2005; Grewal and MacDermid, 2007), and one at 5 mm (Altissimi et al., 1986).

Very few of the papers that found a statically significant association between one or more measures of radiological displacement and clinical outcome estimated the magnitude or importance of this factor. In our patients the association was highly statistically significant, but the impact on the clinical result surprisingly small. In a recent overview, Ilyas and Jupiter (2010) endorse the view that in closed fractures without associated injuries, radial inclination of > 15°, radial shortening of ≤ 5 mm, radial tilt of < 15° dorsal or 20° volar, and < 2 mm intra-articular step-off are acceptable after closed reduction. The AAOS (2011) recently reviewed the literature and found only moderate evidence to support operative fixation for fractures with post-reduction radial shortening of > 3 mm, dorsal tilt > 10°, or intra-articular displacement or step-off of > 2 mm as opposed to cast fixation.

A number of studies report the results among elderly patients in isolation. Fujii et al. (2002) reviewed 22 patients aged 69 (range 60–88) years with severely displaced fractures that were reduced, pinned, and plastered. At review after 24 (12–53) months, radial shortening > 6 mm indicated a poor clinical outcome. Egol et al. (2010) compared 44 patients over the age of 65 years who had been treated operatively to 46 patients who had been treated conservatively. One year after fracture, the operated patients had better radiographic parameters and grip strength. DASH scores, pain scores, and ROM were the same in the two groups.

Most studies of distal radius fractures in elderly patients have found no association between radiological displacement and clinical outcome (Anzarut et al., 2004; Barton et al., 2007; Dayican et al., 2003; Grewal and MacDermid, 2007; Horne et al., 1990; Jaremko et al., 2007; Jupiter et al., 2002; Kelly et al., 1997; Kumar et al., 2008; Synn et al., 2009; Young and Rayan, 2000).

Roumen et al. (1991) studied 43 patients aged over 55 who had radiological evidence of re-displacement of the distal fracture fragment in POP. Half were re-reduced and stabilized with an external fixator. When reviewed after 6 months, radiographs in the external fixation group were better than the control group, but function was no better than in the control group. There was no correlation between anatomical and functional outcome.

Arora et al. (2009) recommended surgery to 114 patients over the age of 70 years with reduced dorsally displaced fractures that had re-displaced to > 20° dorsal angulation, 3 mm radial shortening, or had an intra-articular step of ≥ 2 mm. Surgery was refused by 61 patients, who continued non-operative treatment without re-reduction (mean follow-up 53 months) and 53 patients were treated surgically with fracture reduction and application of a volar locking plate (mean follow-up 62 months). At final review, there was no significant difference between the two groups with regard to ROM, grip strength, DASH, PRWE, or Green and O’Brien (1978) scores. VAS for pain was significantly higher in the operated group.

In a literature review, Diaz-Garcia et al. (2011) identified 21 English-language papers on the management of patients over 60 years with unstable distal radius fractures. They concluded that cast immobilization gave a worse radiographic outcome, but that the clinical result was that same as in those treated with volar locking plates, external fixation, or K-wire stabilization. The AAOS (2011) found the evidence to be inconclusive to support operative treatment for patients over age 55 with distal radius fractures.

There are indications that clinical improvement is more rapid when skeletal anatomy has been restored (Brogren et al., 2011B; Chen et al., 2007; Chung et al., 2007), and there is often no need for POP after volar plating. Both of these points are of benefit to the patient, but must be weighed against the considerably increased risk of complications (Downing and Karantana, 2008; Hakimi et al., 2010; Jupiter et al., 2002; Sahu et al., 2011; Sügün et al., 2011; Wilcke et al., 2007). In their literature review, Diaz-Garcia et al. (2011) found that there were complications requiring surgery in 11% of patients who had volar plates and 1% in those who had been immobilized in a cast.

It seems fairly well established that only the very most displaced or comminuted fractures in the elderly may possibly benefit from surgery. Elderly patients should be made aware of this before consenting to surgery and also of the very considerable risk of post-operative complications and need for re-operation.

The aim of the present study was to find the limits of fracture malunion that are compatible with a good clinical outcome. Our results indicate that almost all degrees of malunion are compatible with good function, and that poor function may be seen in the presence of normal radiological anatomy. This appears to be in accordance with many previous studies. A Cochrane review (Handoll and Madhok, 2003) was unable even to conclude that reduction of the fracture improves the clinical outcome.

We conclude that the present state of knowledge indicates that the radiological outcome after dorsally displaced distal radius fractures, counter-intuitively, has only a minor influence on long-term clinical outcome. It may be that the considerable resources allocated by many hard-pressed health services to open reduction and internal fixation of distal radius fractures would be better used in other ways. This is especially so for elderly patients who should probably only be treated surgically for the few most-markedly comminuted and displaced fractures.
